# Research Compendium  
   
A **systematic** way to organize research data, analyses, and documentation.  
  
<br>
  
--
  
Good research compendia...  
  
* Keep to the conventions of collaborators/peers (makes it **generalizable**)  
  
--
  
* Keep data, methods, and outputs separate (makes it **reliable** & **generalizable**)      
  
--
  
* Clearly specifies the computational environment to the best of its abilities (makes it **reproducible**)
  
<br>
  
--
  
The structure of an R package already has this!   

---

# An R package as a research compendium    
    
```{r, eval=FALSE}  
SAMPLE_COMPENDIUM  
    |
    ├── DESCRIPTION
    |
    ├── README.md
    |
    ├── LICENSE
    |
    ├── data/
    │   ├── raw_data/       # data obtained from elsewhere
    │   └── derived_data/   # data generated during the analysis
    |
    ├── analysis/           # contains scripts for analyses
        └── analysis.R
    |
    ├── paper/
    │   ├── paper.Rmd       # this is the main document to edit
    │   └── references.bib  # this contains the reference list information
    |
    ├── figures/            # location of the figures produced by the Rmd
    |
    └── templates
        ├── journal-of-archaeological-science.csl
        |                   # this sets the style of citations & reference list
        ├── template.docx   # used to style the output of the paper.Rmd
        └── template.Rmd
```
  
---
  
# Create a package & use the structure  
  
`devtools`  
  
The error message says don't do this anymore!!
```{r, eval=FALSE} 
devtools::create("packagename") 
```
  
<br>
`usethis`  
  
A [package](https://github.com/r-lib/usethis) that automates repetitive tasks in project development.  
```{r, eval=FALSE} 
usethis::create_package("packagename")
```
  
<br>
`rrtools`  
  
A [package](https://github.com/benmarwick/rrtools) that expands `devtools` and contains instructions and templates for a tried & true research compendium:  
```{r, eval=FALSE} 
create_compendium("packagename")
```
